titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat FA728
titlestmt.author: Arranged and described by Anneliese Ostendarp, Ford Foundation Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 15:21:13 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat

physdesc.extent: 19 letter document boxes and 1 half-letter document box

did.abstract:
The Office of Reports, Office Files of Richard Magat were transferred to the Ford Foundation Archives with Office of Reports files in at least five separate sections between 1982 and 1986. Because there was no discernible distinction between Mr. Magat's office files and Office of Reports records, the decision was made to define as his office files only those files that were clearly created and maintained by Mr. Magat. Additional "Magat files" are interspersed in Office of Reports records. Mr. Magat also served as Special Assistant to the Mayor's Panel on Decentralization of New York City Schools. In 1979 Mr. Magat donated his Panel papers to the Ford Foundation Archives. These papers are included in this collection (Series IV).
The Office Files of Richard Magat cover the years 1961-82 and consist of chronological files, inter-office memoranda, correspondence and some printed material. The files measure 9.25 linear feet.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Speeches, articles, and staff and consultant reports relating to Ford Foundation activities were removed from Mr. Magat's office files and transferred to the appropriate record group. For each removed item a cross-reference sheet was inserted. Drafts of letters, reports, and press releases were removed except in cases where no final copy could be found or where they differed substantially from the final copy.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Richard Magat was a member of the Ford Foundation staff from 1957 until 1982. Throughout his career at the Foundation Mr. Magat worked in the Office of Reports. He held the following positions:

As Director and Editor, Mr. Magat was responsible for: preparing press releases, writing notes to editors and drafting letters to congressmen; writing and editing Foundation publications and articles including the Annual Report, Current Interests, and Ford Foundation Letter; recommending public reports on Foundation activity; responding to media inquiries and arranging press conferences; and administering the Office of Reports.
Mr. Magat also held the following positions:
1947-51, Dayton Daily News, Ohio, The Binghamton Sun, New York, Reporter
1951-52, McGraw-Hill Book Company, Editor in Technical Writing Service
1953-57, New York University, Senior News Writer, Office of Information Services
1967, Mayor's Advisory Panel on Decentralization of NYC Schools, Special Assistant
1975, Joint Committee for the Reappraisal of the Role of the Red Cross, Editor
1979, SUNY (New York) Fashion Institute of Technology, Instructor

Mr. Magat was born January 1, 1927. He received his A.B. degree in 1947 from New York University. Mr. Magat took additional courses at Columbia University, New York University and the New School. Mr. Magat is the author of Ford Foundation at Work, New York: Plenum (1979), and As Others See Us, Geneva: Henry Dumant Institute (1975). He also wrote articles for Saturday Review, Consumer Reports, Trans-action and other magazines and journals. Mr. Magat left the Ford Foundation in September 1982 to become President of the Edward W. Hazen Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Office Files consist of 9.25 linear feet of correspondence, memoranda, chronological files, and printed material. They document the activities and concerns of Mr. Magat between 1961 and 1982 in his position as Director and Editor of the Office of Reports.

The Office Files of Richard Magat not only reflect the administrative aspects of the Office of Reports but also Mr. Magat's concern for accurate media reporting for Foundation activities and the areas of interest of the Foundation between 1961 and 1982. Some of these areas of interest include: the Patman Committee hearings, the 1969 Tax Reform Act, the Mayor's Panel on Decentralization of NYC Schools, "l'affaire F.O.R.D." [Families Opposing Revolutionary Donations], a proposed communications satellite, and retrenchment at the Foundation. The people with whom Mr. Magat corresponded include: Foundation officers Howard Dressner, Harold Howe II, Mitchell Sviridoff and McGeorge Bundy; literary agent Rick Balkin; press contacts Jeff Birnbaum, Herbert Mitgang and Ted Slate; and individuals at the Council on Foundations, Russell Sage Foundation, Grants Magazine and Foundation News.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: It was not possible to reconstruct the original order of the files. Series arrangement is artificial and includes the following four series:
IV. Mayor's Panel on Decentralization of NYC

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Inter-office Memoranda, documents Mr. Magat's administrative duties in the Office of Reports. The memoranda also show some of Mr. Magat's concerns: the potential for conflict of interest by employing journalists as Foundation consultants; "flaps"--controversial issues with which the Foundation was involved; and the relationship between the Ford Foundation and the Ford Motor Company. The series is divided into five subseries: general memoranda, McGeorge Bundy, Howard Dressner, Franklin Thomas, and Brock Brower. There is some duplication between the first subseries and the four others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following five subseries which are arranged chronologically:
Within each folder the material is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries A, General Inter-office Memoranda, 1961-1982, consists of Richard Magat's outgoing memoranda. The memoranda are addressed to the Office of Reports staff and the other individuals in the Ford Foundation. There is some duplication between this subseries and the following subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries B, McGeorge Bundy, 1966-1979, contains Magat's outgoing memoranda addressed to President Bundy. Also included in this subseries is "Bundy's Out of Town Appearances (1972-1974), itineraries, appointment schedules and arrangements with public relations firms for Bundy's visits to cities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries C, Howard Dressner, 1972-1982, contains Magat's inter-office memoranda addressed to Howard Dressner, Secretary and General Counsel (1971-1984).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries D, Franklin Thomas, 1979-1982, contains Magat's inter-office memoranda addressed to Franklin Thomas, President of the Ford Foundation (1979-1996).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries E, Brock Brower, 1981-1982, contains Magat's memoranda addressed to Brock Brower, who served as Advisor to the President and who was responsible for external dissemination of the results of Ford Foundation programs (1981-1983).

physdesc.extent: 5 letter document boxes and 1 half-letter box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Chronological Files, shows Mr. Magat's activities with non-Foundation individuals. This series includes the outgoing correspondence addressed to literary agents, media and publishing contacts, freelance writers, copy editors, and colleagues at other foundations. The series also includes some of Mr. Magat's responses to requests for information from interested individuals and a small amount of incoming correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in chronological order. Within each folder the items are in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Press Files, demonstrates Mr. Magat's contact with the press: "responding fully to media inquiries.... [and calling] media attention to significant work supported by the Foundation." (Magat to Heard, 1979 Jan. 24, Chronological Files.) The files contain Mr. Magat's outgoing correspondence to his press contacts, often suggesting a story which might be written. The series is divided into two subseries: New York Times press contact files and general press contact files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following two subseries:
A. New York Times Press Files, 1965-1982 B. General Press Files, 1973-1981 (press contacts except the NYT)
Both subseries contain Mr. Magat's outgoing correspondence to press contacts. The subseries are arranged in chronological order. Within each folder the material is in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: Mayor's Panel on Decentralization of NYC Schools

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Mayor's Panel on Decentralization of New York City Schools, contains the materials distributed to the Mayor's Panel for which Mr. Magat served as Special Assistant. The series consists of meeting dockets, reports, correspondence, publications and pamphlets of the Panel for which Magat served as Special Assistant. It is suggested that the researcher use this series in conjunction with the Archives' other holdings on the Mayor's Panel.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in this series was divided by type and arranged chronologically. The list of the original order, "Panel Document File" is in folder 187a of this series.
